metadata.preacher: Not explicitly mentioned in text (delivered at Christ Church, Savannah)
metadata.sermon_start_end: Do you have any family secrets? Most families do. In fact, I think all families do. There was a sister who was an alcoholic, a great-grandfather who served time for tax fraud, an uncle who committed suicide, an ancestor who had a slave mistress. [...] No one will ever be able to despise you or discredit you or discount you, because he has taken all the discounting and discrediting and despising unto himself. Now you are free, free to go forth and strengthen your brothers and sisters. He has paid the price and won the victory. The Lord is risen indeed! Alleluia!
metadata.historical_context: Delivered in a historic Episcopal church in Savannah, Georgia. The year 2000 context reflects a post-modern sensitivity to family dysfunction and a critique of 'sanitized' corporate leadership.
metadata.notes: The sermon employs a narrative-theological style typical of the New Homiletic.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: The sermon excels in creating a 'cinematic' experience, particularly through the recurring motif of the 'look' of Jesus. Following Paul Scott Wilson’s 'show, don’t tell' principle, the preacher reconstructs the courtyard scene with sensory precision. The imagery of the 'bottomless look' serves as a visual anchor for the entire message. However, the imagery occasionally leans toward the familiar (the mustard seed, the fishing boat), which prevents a higher score. The strength lies in the psychological depth of the imagery—the 'mask' and the 'sanitized biography'—which translates abstract guilt into a visual, modern reality. The use of Psalm 139 to describe the 'knitting together' provides a tactile counterpoint to the 'tearing apart' of Peter’s denial.
quotes: In that moment, the abject failure of the human creature was met by the penetrating gaze of the One who was on his way to be handed over.
Peter’s faith was no better than a castle made of sand until the risen Lord remade him.
The description of the maid 'seeing him as he sat in the light and gazing at him'.
strengths: Strong central metaphor (the Gaze) that unifies the text.
Effective use of modern analogies (medicine cabinets, tax fraud) to ground biblical themes.
Vivid reconstruction of the biblical scene that places the hearer in the courtyard.
improvement_points: Incorporate more sensory details beyond sight (smell of the fire, cold of the night).
Avoid over-familiar metaphors like 'mustard seed' without fresh reframing.
Deepen the 'castle made of sand' image to make it less of a cliché.
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: Strongly leans toward 'showing' by reconstructing the gaze of Jesus rather than merely defining 'grace' or 'forgiveness'.

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: The language is exceptionally precise, reflecting Marilyn Chandler McEntyre’s 'stewardship of language.' The preacher avoids 'Canaanite jargon,' opting for words like 'restitution,' 'rectification,' and 'reconstitution' to explain 'justification' in a way that feels fresh and legally/relationally accurate. There is a deliberate care in distinguishing between 'forgiveness' and 'justification,' showing a high level of theological nuance without becoming academic. The word choice is economical; every sentence serves to either build the narrative or deepen the theological reflection. The use of the 'family secret' analogy at the start is a precise rhetorical hook that avoids sentimentality.
quotes: Paul, instead of using the word 'forgiven,' uses the word 'justified' — not only forgiven, but also made right, rectified, reconstituted.
There were no psychological undercurrents in his look, no overtones of neurosis or displaced anger or rampant superego.
Stories about their failures of character do not lie at the heart of these sanitized books.
strengths: Excellent translation of dogmatic terms into accessible, precise English.
Avoidance of religious clichés through the use of psychological and legal terminology.
Clear, rhythmic sentence structure that aids oral comprehension.
improvement_points: The list of 'I would never' sins (hit and run, medicine cabinet) is slightly long and could be more focused.
Ensure the distinction between 'wrath' and 'love' remains linguistically sharp to avoid confusion.
The transition to the Emmaus road text is slightly abrupt in its phrasing.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Theological jargon is intentionally deconstructed and replaced with precise, contemporary synonyms (e.g., 'rectification' for 'justification').

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: The sermon possesses a clear oral cadence. The repetition of the phrase 'And the Lord turned and looked at Peter' acts as a liturgical refrain, creating a rhythmic pulse. The preacher uses variation in sentence length effectively—short, punchy sentences for dramatic emphasis ('Peter tried to hide, but the Lord found him') followed by longer, flowing theological expositions. The use of alliteration ('discounting and discrediting and despising') at the conclusion provides a strong rhetorical finish. While it lacks the high poetic quality of a 'prose poem,' it is perfectly crafted for the ear, avoiding the 'paper language' of a lecture.
quotes: And the Lord turned and looked at Peter. Imagine it, if you will.
No one will ever be able to despise you or discredit you or discount you...
Peter was not being arrested; Peter was not being tried; Peter was not being executed.
strengths: Effective use of repetition (anaphora) to build emotional weight.
Natural oral rhythm that avoids bureaucratic or overly complex syntax.
Strong use of rhetorical triads (despise, discredit, discount).
improvement_points: Some mid-sections with long biblical quotes break the rhythmic flow of the preacher's own voice.
Increase the use of assonance or alliteration in the more descriptive passages.
The transition between the 'parents' look' and the 'Psalm 139' section could be more melodically linked.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: Distinctly oral language; the structure and rhythm suggest it was composed specifically for performance.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The poetics of the sermon are characterized by a 'sober beauty.' The language is precise, avoiding the pitfalls of religious jargon by employing contemporary psychological and relational terms. The imagery of the 'Gaze' is the aesthetic heart of the piece, successfully 'showing' the interaction of judgment and grace. While it avoids high-flown poeticism, its strength lies in its clarity, rhythmic refrains, and the 'stewardship of words' that makes the ancient text feel immediate and physically present.

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a classic 'Lowry Loop' or narrative plot. It begins by 'upsetting the equilibrium' with the concept of family secrets, immediately creating a 'mystery' about why Peter's failure was preserved. The tension builds through the denial scene until it reaches the 'bottomless look' of Jesus—the turning point of the sermon. The movement from the 'wrath' of self-discovery to the 'restitution' of Easter morning is handled with dramatic skill. The preacher maintains the tension of Peter's despair ('nothing else to hope for') before introducing the '...and Peter' resolution. It is a dynamic journey from the 'unmasking' of the hearer to their 'reconstitution' in Christ.
quotes: Tonight we are going to ask ourselves why the church preserved and retold a terrible story about the apostle Peter.
As far as anyone knew, it was the end of the story of Jesus of Nazareth.
Go and tell the disciples and Peter! ... even Peter!
strengths: Clear, compelling opening that creates an immediate 'need to know'.
Strong movement from the 'trouble' (denial/guilt) to the 'grace' (restitution).
The 'turning point' is not just a theological statement but a dramatic encounter.
improvement_points: The section on the 'designers of the lectionary' feels like a brief meta-commentary that slightly distracts from the narrative flow.
The conclusion could lean more into the 'open ending' of the hearer's life.
The transition from Peter's weeping to Easter morning is very fast; more 'Saturday' tension could be explored.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: A dynamic journey that moves from a human problem (secrets/shame) to a divine resolution (restitution).

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: The sermon achieves 'reframing' by placing the hearer's modern anxieties (divorce, professional failure, private sins) within the frame of Peter’s denial. Cilliers’ concept of 'inter-esse' is visible as the preacher moves between the 1st-century courtyard and the 21st-century medicine cabinet. The 'strangeness' of the biblical text—the fact that it preserves such a shameful story—is used as the bridge to the context of our own 'sanitized' lives. The synthesis is organic; the preacher doesn't 'apply' the text at the end, but rather weaves the hearer into the text throughout. However, the context remains largely individual/familial, with less attention to broader social 'reframing'.
quotes: Think of all the people who have said... 'until death us do part'; they meant it at the time, but half of them are now divorced.
You know how it is when you hear someone being critical of someone else, and you think to yourself, 'If only she knew...'
In the light of the resurrection message, we may give up pretense and denial forever.
strengths: Surprising and natural connection between 'family secrets' and the Gospel tradition.
Honors the 'strangeness' of the text (why would they keep this story?).
Effective 'reframing' of the hearer's self-perception through the lens of the 'Gaze'.
improvement_points: Broaden the context to include communal or societal 'denials' to increase the scope of reframing.
The connection to the Emmaus road text feels slightly less integrated than the rest.
Ensure the 'modern sins' list doesn't feel like a random 'grab bag'.
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: Yes; it reframes human failure not as something to be hidden (the 'sanitized biography') but as the very site of divine restitution.

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: Based on Ciska Stark's 'open work of art,' the sermon is moderately successful. It invites the hearer into the 'courtyard' and asks them to feel the 'look.' It acknowledges the 'ambivalence of existence' by refusing to offer a 'cheap' happy ending—Peter’s failure is real and bitter. However, the conclusion is somewhat 'sealed' with a very traditional, declarative Alleluia. While theologically sound, it moves quickly to resolve all tensions. The sermon is more 'polyvalent' in its middle section (the psychological depth of the look) than in its ending, which leans toward a monovalent, prescriptive assurance.
quotes: Imagine it, if you will. Peter was the motormouth...
Perhaps you think you are a person of little faith...
Now you are free, free to go forth and strengthen your brothers and sisters.
strengths: Leaves room for the hearer to identify their own 'denials' without being overly moralistic.
Acknowledges the 'dark side' and the reality of being a 'total fraud'.
Approaches the hearer as a conversation partner in the 'family secret' of the church.
improvement_points: The ending is very 'resolved'; leaving a lingering question about the 'Galilee' of the hearer's life could increase openness.
Allow more room for the 'silence' of Holy Saturday before the Easter resolution.
Avoid the 'Now you are free' declaration in favor of an invitation to 'step into' that freedom.
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: Primarily a 'closed' work in its theological resolution, but 'open' in its narrative invitation and psychological realism.

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The macro-aesthetic quality is high, driven by a strong narrative arc that respects the 'trouble' of the text. The preacher avoids a static three-point sermon, opting for a journey that moves from the 'unmasking' of the human condition to the 'reconstitution' of the person in Christ. The integration of text and context is seamless, using the 'family secret' motif to bridge two millennia. While the ending is somewhat dogmatically closed, the overall dramaturgy creates a powerful 'event' of encounter with the divine gaze.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: The sermon is remarkably free of religious kitsch. It avoids the 'pre-chewed emotions' of typical Easter sentimentality by dwelling on the 'bitter weeping' and the 'total fraud' of the apostle. The preacher explicitly rejects 'sanitized' versions of the story. By addressing the 'wrath of God' and the 'fearful mercy,' the sermon sustains the tension between judgment and grace. It does not offer a 'happy ending' without first taking the 'pain of suffering' and the 'abject failure' seriously. The emotion feels authentic because it is rooted in the 'unmasking' of the self, rather than in manipulative sentiment.
examples_of_kitsch: The 'mustard seed' reference is the closest the sermon comes to a religious cliché.
The 'castle made of sand' metaphor is slightly sentimental but serves a clear purpose.
authentic_moments: The description of Peter as a 'total fraud' who has 'nowhere left to stand'.
The critique of 'sanitized biographies' in contrast to the raw honesty of the Gospels.
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: Maintain this 'sober' approach to grace; avoid the slight 'Alleluia' rush at the very end to let the weight of the restitution sink in further.

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: The sermon is a textbook example of Cilliers' 'Space for Grace.' It creates a 'space' by unmasking the hearer's pretensions, leaving them, like Peter, with 'nowhere left to stand.' In this vacuum of human effort, the 'penetrating gaze' of Christ enters not as a moralistic demand, but as a 'reconstituting' force. The mystery of the '...and Peter' message is respected as a 'wonderful' surprise that the hearer cannot earn. The preacher successfully avoids 'moralization' (telling people to be better) in favor of 'grace' (showing how they are remade).
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: Yes; the tension between Peter's 'passionate protestations' and his 'craven self-serving falsehoods' is held until the very moment of the Easter message.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: Yes; the 'bottomless look' is treated as a mystery of 'aweful love' rather than a psychological puzzle to be solved.
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: Grace prevails. The 'strengthen your brethren' command is presented as a fruit of grace, not a condition for it.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: To open even more space, the preacher could acknowledge the 'not yet'—that even after restitution, we still struggle with denial.

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon is an aesthetically robust example of the 'New Homiletic' with a strong Reformed-Episcopal emphasis on the 'sober beauty' of the Word. Its primary aesthetic power lies in its 'optics'—the ability to make the hearer 'see' the gaze of Christ and 'feel' the unmasking of their own 'sanitized' lives. The preacher avoids the 'kitsch' of easy comfort by dwelling in the bitterness of Peter's failure, thereby making the eventual 'restitution' feel earned and authentic. The language is precise and oral, and the narrative arc is expertly paced. While the conclusion is slightly more 'closed' and traditional than the 'open work of art' ideal might suggest, the sermon successfully creates a 'space for grace' where the 'holy happens' through the intersection of biblical narrative and human vulnerability.
strengths_top_3: The central motif of the 'Gaze' as a visual and theological anchor.
The 'anti-kitsch' honesty regarding human failure and the 'total fraud' of the self.
The seamless integration of modern analogies (family secrets, corporate biographies) with the biblical text.
improvement_points_top_3: Increase the 'openness' of the conclusion to allow the hearer more room for personal appropriation.
Refine the 'mustard seed' and 'sand castle' metaphors to match the originality of the rest of the sermon.
Smooth the transition between the different biblical citations to maintain the narrative flow.
overall_aesthetics.primary_aesthetic_style: Narrative-Dramatic with a focus on 'Psychological Realism'.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Fits Paul Scott Wilson's 'Four Pages' (strong imagery and balance of trouble/grace) and Johan Cilliers' 'Reframing' (looking at reality through the lens of the Gaze).
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Aesthetically appeals to 'modern seekers' and 'intellectually honest' believers who are weary of religious pretense and 'sanitized' faith.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Experiment with an 'open ending' that leaves the hearer in the 'Galilee' of their own week.
Incorporate more sensory language (sound, touch) to complement the strong visual imagery.
Deepen the 'Holy Saturday' tension to make the Easter 'event' even more performative.
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: The sermon is an aesthetically successful 'event' that honors the 'aesthetic turn' in homiletics. It does not merely talk about grace; it attempts to 'perform' grace by unmasking the hearer and then 'reconstituting' them through the narrative of Peter. It is a work of 'sober beauty' that avoids the pitfalls of both dry intellectualism and kitschy emotionalism. By focusing on the 'look' of Jesus, the preacher provides a 'new optics' for the congregation to see themselves and God.
